statement.text: The marginal artery of Drummond is a continuous arterial arcade running along the mesenteric border of the colon, connecting branches of the SMA and IMA, with critical watershed zones at Griffiths point (splenic flexure) and Sudeck point (rectosigmoid junction) where the arcade may be incomplete or attenuated.
statement.formal: Marginal_Artery: Ileocolic → Right_Colic → Middle_Colic → Left_Colic → Sigmoid → Superior_Rectal (Watershed: Griffiths_Point, Sudeck_Point)

explanation.intuition: Picture a continuous blood vessel running along the inside edge of the entire colon like a highway, with on-ramps from the SMA arteries (right side) and IMA arteries (left side). At two spots - near the splenic flexure and at the rectosigmoid - this highway gets narrow or may have gaps, making these areas vulnerable when blood supply is reduced.
explanation.key_insight: The marginal artery is the final common pathway for colonic blood supply. Understanding its watershed zones explains why splenic flexure and rectosigmoid junction are most vulnerable to ischemia during hypotension, aortic surgery, or IMA ligation. These same areas are preferentially involved in ischemic colitis.
explanation.technical_details: The marginal artery runs 1-2 cm from the mesenteric border of the colon, connecting all colic branches (ileocolic → right colic → middle colic → left colic → sigmoid → superior rectal). It gives off vasa recta to the bowel wall. Griffiths point: junction of middle colic (SMA) and left colic (IMA) territories at splenic flexure - marginal artery absent/small in 5-50%. Sudeck point: junction of sigmoid and superior rectal arteries at rectosigmoid - critical point for last sigmoid branch. During AAA repair with IMA ligation, these watersheds determine ischemia risk. Post-op sigmoid ischemia most common after aortic surgery.

anatomy.course: Mesenteric border of colon, 1-2 cm from wall
anatomy.connections: Links ileocolic, right colic, middle colic, left colic, sigmoid, superior rectal
anatomy.vasa_recta: Short and long branches supply bowel wall

griffiths_point.significance: Vulnerable in SMA or IMA occlusion

sudeck_point.significance: Critical for sigmoid viability after IMA ligation

aortic_surgery.IMA_ligation: Safe if marginal artery intact and backbleeding adequate
aortic_surgery.risk_factors: Hypotension, prior radiation, atherosclerosis of arc
aortic_surgery.monitoring: Colonoscopy or sigmoidoscopy if concern for ischemia

clinical_significance.colon_surgery: Preserve marginal artery when possible during resection

imaging.CTA: Coronal reconstructions show marginal artery course

definition.@value: Continuous arterial arcade along the mesenteric border of the colon connecting SMA and IMA branches, with vulnerable watershed zones at Griffiths point (splenic flexure) and Sudeck point (rectosigmoid).

learning_objectives: Trace the marginal artery of Drummond along the colon
Identify the two critical watershed zones
Understand why splenic flexure and rectosigmoid are vulnerable to ischemia
clinical_pearls: Griffiths point (splenic flexure) - marginal artery absent in up to 50%
Sudeck point (rectosigmoid) - last sigmoid branch critical for sigmoid viability
Ischemic colitis preferentially affects watershed zones - look there first
After AAA repair with IMA ligation, SIGMOID is most commonly ischemic
Check backbleeding from IMA stump during AAA repair - guides reimplantation decision
